His fingers finally found the right button without much help from his eyes and switched off the recording. He grimaced at the covered window, at a stinging slice of light that had found its way past the heavy curtains, and reached to try to arrange them but only managed to upset them more. Shielding his eyes from the sunshine with one arm, he slid out of bed and made his way to the dresser to find something to wear. Then to the shower, silently, as usual. He dried off and got dressed in the washroom as he always did, then opened the medicine cabinet and picked up the lone orange pill bottle on the shelf. He looked at it for a long moment, studying the label, and gave it a shake. No rattle. He had taken the last one the morning before, but had not been able to bring himself to throw it away yet. Jamie could not actually remember the last time he hadn't owned one of these, although intellectually he knew it had begun when he was sixteen. It had been such an easy rhythm after the first few years, with refills every three months and no gap between. He'd come to think of the bottle as something at least as permanent as a shoe or a fork, something that felt strange to get rid of despite its current uselessness. Now and for the foreseeable future - or so said the powers that be - Jamie didn't need those pills anymore. He uncapped the bottle, recapped it, and placed it back on the shelf in its proper spot. Maybe he'd keep this part of his routine for a little longer. Just in case everything else fell apart. :~: All he knew was that they should be kissing. He had thought himself a late bloomer when he was younger, but by the time he had turned twenty he was convinced that he would never bloom at all. Hermione was saying something, he was vaguely aware, about their astronomy class for the coming year, and had been doing so for some time. "What, you didn't know it was the name of a star, too? Here, see this map, in the constellation Canis Majoris--" "Canis Majoris? Canis as in canine? Sirius is in the Big Dog constellation?" "And another name for it is the Dog Star. You needn't sound so disbelieving, Harry. It makes sense, doesn't it?" "But how could his parents possibly know he'd turn out to be a dog animagus?" "Maybe he grew into his name, and just sort of got doggier and doggier..." "'Doggier,' you say? Is somebody talking about me?" came Sirius's amused voice. Harry dropped the textbook, which Hermione caught smoothly and began flipping through the pages to recover her lost place. "It's nothing bad, Sirius. We were just talking about your name star." She showed him the diagram, and Sirius smiled. There was an edge to it, Harry thought, but it made his strained look lighten for at least a moment, dissolving into bright affection. "It's not just an ordinary star, though," he informed them, still glinting. "It's binary - there's two stars to it, that orbit each other so closely that nobody could even tell there were two except that they tend to wobble around in the sky. On top of that, it's usually the brightest star... Pick your jaw up off the floor, Hermione. My name star, remember? Nobody would be shocked if you knew your name's origins." "...Winter's Tale," mumbled Hermione, actually abashed. "Are they both called Sirius?" This query being met by blank looks, Harry amended, "the stars, the ones orbiting each other?" "I guess so," replied Sirius thoughtfully. "But if the big one is the Dog Star, do you know what the little one's called?" "It must be something like... the Wolf Star?" ventured Hermione, who had not quite finished the textbook yet. "Good try, but no. Five points from Gryffindor. Kidding! I'm kidding," he nearly shouted, recoiling when he saw Hermione's expression. "What is it called?" Harry pressed curiously. Sirius met Harry's eyes warmly, reaching out to ruffle his already unruly hair. "The Pup." :~

But now Jamie was here, in Geoff's new flat, inexplicable as always. He'd come for his visit late yesterday, and startled Geoff by hugging the breath out of him as soon as he was in reach. They had a week to spend together. It looked as though Jamie intended to fill it with the maximum of oddness. As to the manifestation of that oddness: well, it had happened once before. Only once, some two months before Jamie left. He had supposed it to be thanks for comforting Jamie after one of his night terrors. Those flowers had been on the table when he'd returned from class the next day, bound with a bit of twine same as these. These were types he recognised, though; the other ones, although vaguely familiar, he had not had names to put to. He had, however, made note of them in his journal at the time, which shouldn't be too hard to locate. Geoff dug that up out of his things in only a few minutes, and laid it open next to the new bouquet to compare. Same twine. Same pattern, really: two types of flowers and a little branch of leaves. The note beside a rough sketch of the previous boquet of unnamed flowers reminded him that he had thanked Jamie that evening, but Jamie had just blinked at him. If he thought of this phenomenon as a case, it had never been closed, and was certainly live now. So... current notebook, pen, his new digital camera - check. He recorded the new bouquet with a brief sketch to scale, a photo, and a list of the contents, since he recognised the flowers at least. Three stalks of purple hyacinth were bound to a single stem of geranium, accompanied by greenery of some sort. He outlined its leaf in his notebook, ran a copy of the old bouquet's page and stapled it in, and put his fresh flowers in a glass of water on the windowsill. Geoff went over his investigatory options. Jamie hadn't answered his direct approach last time, so there was no reason to think he would this time. In fact, this felt distinctly like some sort of game. Since Jamie was out, he could nip over to the library and get a flower identification guide in an hour or less without being obvious about it. Geoff was halfway to the library on his motorbike when a sign for cut flowers caught his eye. He turned around and pulled in, looking curiously through the windows. The place was open, and upon entering he found it very full of plants, so much so that any till or workstation there might be was hidden at first. But rounding a potted shrubbery, he located a window with a bit of counter at the bottom, and a silver bell sitting out. He rang it once, and waited. Presently a short, dark woman who looked to be somewhere in her fifties appeared, gloved and muddy. She stuck her face out the little aperture. "Can I help ye?" "Er, I hope so," said Geoff. "I was given some flowers, and I'm not sure what they are. Might you be able to identify them?" "Let's have a look, then." Geoff set his notes on the counter, and was relieved when she didn't pick them up, just leaned over, squinting at them. "Heh. Not a bad little doodle, there. I think I can tell ye. This," she pointed to the first bouquet, "is milk vetch. Tied with thornapple, and of course that's a fern. And the other, well... Looks like you know what hyacinth is, that's good. Geranium, aye. The greens are wormwood, by this leaf you've drawn." She looked up. "Will that be all?" "Well." Geoff pressed his lips together thoughtfully. "I'm also not too sure... should I give flowers in return? I just don't know the etiquette of it." "Eh, lad. I couldn't swear t' this, but it looks as though with this one here," she gestured to that morning's flowers, "Somebody's trying to apologise t' you." "Really? How can you tell?" "In the language o' the flowers, hyacinth of this colour means forgive me, unless I'm much mistaken. Purple, correct?" "Yes. Language of the flowers? You mean like a red rose means love and a yellow one means just friends?" "Close enough. 'Twas a Victorian practise, revelling in their repression and all that. I'd say giving flowers back is up t' you, now, but ye'd best tell her if she's forgiven." "Erm. Okay..." "Do you want to give something? If you want to say back that it's alright - or that it's not - I can put you something together." "I suppose... yes. I would like to try. It's a kind of a code, isn't it." "It certainly is! Now. What are you wanting to say?" "That it's alright. That there's nothing to apologise for. Can you do that?" "Of course we can! Let me get my book down." A quarter-hour later, Geoff was riding home with a carefully shielded little clutch of flowers: white jasmine with apple blossoms and a sprig of white ivy tendrils, which disappeared from the table that afternoon after Jamie came back to the flat. Jamie and Geoff had lunch. They played video games. They had a walk out to the river, and a nap in the den, and a late dinner of cold pizza. Geoff tried not to think about the flowers. Title: Lookalike Author: Starring: Jamie & Geoff Rating: G Disclaimer: The way I can imagine is not the true Way. Notes: Beta and much-needed encouragement by . ~: "Are you Charlie Pace?" Geoff blinked at the stranger addressing him, who was staring at him with an expression uncomfortably close to worship. "...No. Who?" "You. You look just like him. You're sure?" "Sure that I'm not somebody else?" Heh. "Yes. Very Sure. Geoff Shawcross." He put out his hand, attempting to salvage the situation, but the other lad only glanced at it. And resumed staring. "Very sure," he repeated reluctantly. Geoff supposed most people would be more discomfited at this point, but curiosity had already taken over, and he was finding the encounter oddly charming. He smiled and met the other's eyes, who looked away, flushing, then kept peeking back. "Who are you?" Geoff inquired gently. "Jamie Holmes, good afternoon how are you I'm fine, thanks very much." ... "And who is it I look like?" Jamie seemed to expand a little with held-in excitement. "The bassist from DriveSHAFT. You look just like him, so much. Only your hair is different. He's my favourite," he added unnecessarily. "Sorry to disappoint you." "Oh, no! Not a disappointment, this, not at all, I mean... I'm not at all sure I'd survive meeting him for real. Suspect my head would explode." Geoff chuckled, and Jamie smiled a little and seemed to relax marginally. "And you do look so like him. It's like meeting him, only without the brains everywhere." "And without the music." Geoff was trying to remember what desperately overplayed song it was that DriveSHAFT had done, without success. "And without the music," Jamie agreed. "Or crowds or groupies to fight off. Lucky, that." "I know, man, I've never been so glad not to be famous." "Just..." Jamie fell silent, lifting his eyes to Geoff's face, taking him in. Geoff felt almost pinned by his gaze, not wanting to disturb the image he seemed to be saving. He wondered a bit awkwardly if Jamie was seeing him or that musician. At last he was released when Jamie looked away. The quiet had grown long and heavy; Geoff was about to try saying something - anything - to end the silence, when Jamie spoke again. "So I know all about Charlie Pace, but he doesn't know me. And he has no reason to take the time to talk to me, even if I could... But." He smiled, a sweet, impish grin. "Neither does Geoff Shawcross have any reason, yet here you are." Geoff tilted his head, amused. "True enough." "Which, to me, means..." his forehead wrinkled, "hold on a moment." Jamie fumbled in his pockets, came up with a pen and a scrap of receipt, and scribbled something on the back. He looked up - "it means, I think, that you might email me as well." He thrust the piece of paper into Geoff's hand, ducked his head, and beat a determined retreat, scuttling hastily around the corner of a nearby storefront. Geoff pondered pursuing him, but discarded that idea quickly. No point in freaking the guy out any further than he was already freaked. Which seemed a considerable amount. The paper in his hand contained a barely legible email address and a scrawl that was probably Jamie. He tucked it into his wallet, thinking that he might just use it after all. Now, back to his errand... ...Of which he had no memory whatsoever. Even logic and extrapolation couldn't jar loose the knowledge of what he was out here to do, not after that thorough of a distraction. He got his mobile out, preparing himself to be savagely teased by Hetty for this. In his head, he was already composing an email to Jamie about it. :~

Title: O' Sailor Author: Starring: Jamie/Geoffrey Rating: PG Disclaimer: The way I can imagine is not the true Way. Notes: This story may make you hungry. Or the opposite, if you don't like eggs. It has nothing whatsoever to do with the Fiona Apple song of the same title. Beta by . :~ "What smells so fantastic?" Geoff wanders in, half dressed. I try to keep my mind on cooking, but have to turn and smile at him. Can't forget to flip them. "It's only eggs and toast. Anything smells fantastic to you before breakfast." I can't forget to flip them. The timing is delicate. They'll burn. He leans towards the range, inhaling. "Mutant eggs and toast, then." Geoff thinks it's funny that Asperger Syndrome (basically, me) is considered a mutation, and brings it up every chance he gets. I think it's some sort of X-Men thing. Well, Nightcrawler is cool. Can't forget, can't forget. "Never had much luck with the normal kind. Yolks always break. This is sort of a protein-carbohydrate boost. My mum taught me." My eyes are trained on the edge of the bread. Geoff sidles in for a kiss; it's just a greeting smooch, so I let him. I can't take my attention away from breakfast, or it'll ruin. I wave him off with the spatula. It's hard to say whether the grumbling noise he makes on the way out to fetch the paper is his voice or his stomach. I hope the neighbours enjoy the show. He's forgot his trousers again. The white parts are looking pretty well solidified. I probably present the appearance of a bomb squad member attempting to defuse toast with an egg in the middle. Flipping eggs is about all the drama I can take in the morning. One, two, three, four... each piece flops by turn into place on the pan, and without so much as a drip of yolk. That's victory. "They done yet?" I don't bother to reply - me still hovering over them with my spatula ought to make it clear enough. It's only about a minute, though, before I can bring down plates and deposit two slices onto each. Geoff is at my elbow, and accepts his plate before I quite get it to the table. "These are definitely weird," he says happily as we spread the yellow around atop white-infiltrated bread. "And delicious," he adds around a mouthful. The white part of the egg is rightly known as albumen, but Geoff doesn't let me call it that while he's eating. He gestures at his food with his fork. "Is there a name for them?" "One-eyed sailors," I tell him, deadpan, and he nearly chokes laughing, then swats me with the Arts & Entertainment section. It's particularly bulky on Tuesdays. "No wonder you like them!" "No wonder." I'm only halfway through my first piece, and he's well into his second. Then again, he isn't bothering to dip the crust in the yolk. I am suddenly so intensely happy that I interrupt his eating to give him a real kiss. "I feel really good today," I say by way of explanation. "I can tell." It's not usual for me to be up to cooking by myself, especially early in the day. It takes way too much RAM. "...I was really hungry today," he adds a bit piteously, and he's setting himself up for it now. "Aye, and the sun came up, too. But if you want another one-eyed sailor, you'd better be making it yourself." And then we're just grinning at each other like fools. :~: One-Eyed Sailors (Very exacting directions suitable even for other non-cooks.) What you need:     Slices of bread that are porus and not too small to soak up most of the egg-white. Also, the crust shouldn't be taller than the bread itself, especially if the texture of the white gives you trouble.     One egg per slice.     Butter or whatever you prefer to use.     A nice big pan of good temperament.     A spatula or other flipping device.     A fork. Heat the pan until the butter will turn clear and bubble slightly on it. Melt a little butter in the spot so that it'll kind of butter the bread as you lay it in. Tear a hole out of the centre of your slice of bread that is only a wee bit bigger than you suspect the yolk will be. Eat the middle bit, so you're not too hungry while cooking (the cook always eats last). Lay the bread into the pan, then break an egg into the middle. Lift up the bread a tiny bit so that the albumen can reach all the way under the bread, and spread what's not soaked in around evenly on the top with the fork. Wait until you can tell the white in the centre is not going to be runny on the other side and the yolk is cooked into place enough to turn over without going everywhere, then flip it. If you can, place it in a spot with a little more butter melted there. You can flip it as many more times as you need if it didn't finish on the other side. When the yolk looks nicely over-easy on both sides, it is ready to eat. I'm fine with one or two slices, even when I'm hungry, but Geoff swears only three is enough for a proper meal. Take into consideration that he is very pro-breakfast. He also likes pepper on his. Unfortunately, this is the only vaguely pirate-themed recipe I know. :~

No, two Christmasses ago. Never mind what kind of mates give each other pants for Christmas. You gave him that journal, too, didn't you? And if you could turn the thermostat down just one more degree, maybe he'd need one of your jumpers, and-- Nuh uh. That's going a bit far. But he's in your house. He's already surrounded by you. Only not literally. How easy it suddenly is to move to remedy that. Your arms slide around his shoulders from behind, and he does not start at your touch. He breathes deep before looking at you, and stretches that long neck backward, chin to the sky. Ceiling. You rest your cheek on his. You've been thinking. "Bored, Bills?" It occurs that you were supposed to have been reading. A glance over your shoulder shows your book set pages-down and getting a bit rumpled. It would piss you off if you've lost your place, but that really isn't a priority right now, is it? "Getting there." He lets his breath out through his nose like a yawn. His skin smells of... and here your mind fails, because there aren't enough good words for scent in the English language. Hmm. I'd say... brownish-gold. You laugh, and he sits up and twists without shaking off your arms, so his can go around your waist, too, and suddenly you're a hundred times more okay than you were, and you hadn't even noticed if you weren't. "D'you need me t' entertain you? Isn't that your job, host? What do you do when I'm not here?" "Rot, mostly," you confess, and he laughs and you laugh and no, it isn't true, but it feels that way right now. He pulls on your waist, then, hauling himself up out of the chair so that you almost fall, but of course you don't really. Then he's standing there with a vaugely puzzled, curious look. Like should I try juggling, then, what? "Read to me," you say, with no preplanning, and. "Well, maybe you've not read this, and I'm halfway through, but--" "Alright." He leans over (such unlikely angles to him sometimes) and snags the book, a finger where it was open as he flips through. "What, no Kissing In Manhattan?" Rats! That would have been an experience. "Nawp, finished that one. Ehm, from here, then," you point out your place, not lost after all, and he grins and parks himself carelessly on the loveseat, one leg thrown over the armrest. His hair is ridiculous. "Ha-h'm. Here was something that Ford felt he could speak about with authority. Hey, I've read this!" "Have you?" You've settled beside him, not quite relaxed enough. You have the obdurate urge to read over his shoulder. "Ages ago. This is classic! Why'd you take off the dust jacket? Oh, never mind, here goes: 'Life,' he said, 'is like a grapefruit.' 'Er, how so?' 'Well, it's sort of orangey-yellow and dimpled on the outside and squidgy in the middle. It's got pips inside, too. Oh, and some people have half a one for breakfast.' Ha!" says Dom loudly, and you jump a little. "You've never read this before? And you're almost to the good part, why'd you stop? This isn't a boring book, you know," he says with authority. "It's insane." "I was..." you trail off. Not much you can say, really. Well. "I was at a good part." "You were at a good part," he repeats mildly, untroubled. "Yeh. 'Cause." And your hand tugs on the tail of his shirt a little, just kind of a pullpullpull that he'll hardly notice. Your knuckle bumps the soft skin of his side, and he writhes a little, in no position to escape, really, and looks at you. And sighs, and smiles a little glowy smile. And leans over and lets the book slide off his lap, leans on you, and you didn't expect it but he's draped across your lap now, inhaling and exhaling like a monk trained to do it all day for the path to heaven. His arms are heavy, and it can't feel good, your knee digging into wherever it's digging. Dom's weight settles on you, and if you were okay before, now you are... something way better. But you're not thinking too hard about it. "Me too," he says, and you laugh, and kiss his nose, and just, sort of... Yeah. Spend the rest of the evening like that. :~ {The bit Dom reads is from Chapter 23 of So Long And Thanks For All The Fish, by Douglas Adams. No infringement intended.}

Title: Lines Author: Starring: Dom/Billy Rating: PG Summary: Soaking everything in, but still not seeing. Disclaimer: The way that I can imagine is not the true Way. Notes: Beta by . My first publicly posted fic, originally found here. ~: Billy walks behind his Dominic, pondering lines. He knows there's borders to every relation in the world; the one between him and his barber, the one between him and his sister. Always guidelines to follow, certain ways he oughtn't behave. He stays inside the lines. He is very obedient when it counts. He thinks that Dominic has trouble seeing the lines. That maybe he's line-blind. When they are all seated in the booth, he knows it's true. They wind and intercede, blue to Billy's fancy, glowing in the dark of the club. They separate every person and every other. Only, the one between Billy and Dom is getting squished against both of their sides as Dom drapes himself happily over his best mate. "I didn't think pineapple juice and chocolate syrup would go so well," Dom is saying to Sean's doubtful grimace. "That can't be all that's in that drink," Sean says, eyeing the murky liquid. "Mm, I put some of whatever Elijah's drinking in there, too..." Billy and Sean turn wordlessly to Elijah, just waiting for the shoe to drop. He raises his glass cheerily. "It's a Bloody Caesar!" The table erupts in groans and gagging noises. Fingers brush at Billy's neck, work their way around his collar and under his shirt, splaying gently over the skin of his shoulder, just feeling. Billy freezes. Dom is tipped against him, laughing, unaware that anything is amiss. Dom's ring is metal-slick and cornered against his collarbone, but the line between them persists. At least, he thinks it should be. As usual, Dom is the one who can make him doubt. When Peter introduced Dom to the other three hobbits, he took to them all as if they were old friends. Which is easy enough in words, but. Billy was swept away. It was easy to let it become reality, to start as acquaintances being good friends, and God only knows where it will end. Only it won't end - Billy knows that Dom believes it won't. And not one of them would resist that. Even if it wouldn't have been true, they will make it so. It may be contagious. They all dance, and he watches the lines shift and play, more complex between people who are closer. Only Dom doesn't seem to heed them, kissing Sean's jaw tenderly, and later spinning Elijah and dipping him with the lively music until a flush suffuses the pale skin, even his arms... Billy blinks. Got him doing it now; seeing things he's not supposed to notice. It's a bad idea to forget what he knows about reality. He needs that boundary. But then Dom is dancing in front of him, wedging thumbs into his beltloops and palms resting against each hip. Dom's nose bumps forward, cold on Billy's neck, but his face slides hotly against Billy's own, leaving a smear of sweat when he has turned to look at something. Soaking everything in, but still not seeing. And Dom looks Billy in the eyes as they dance, just looks, until Billy breaks away and goes to find another drink, hopefully something with neither clams nor chocolate. Too close, his sensibilities have been screaming. He shushes them, annoyed. What do they know about Dom? Nothing he has learned about human behaviours seems to apply. Dom must be an alien. "What're you thinkin' about?" "What planet are you from?" Dom tilts his head, a smile blooming on his face. "Germany," he says, then crows with laughter. "No! Can I be from one of the moons of Jupiter?" "If you like." Toasting with a hearty, "IO!" Dom drains Billy's glass. :~: When Sean drops Billy off outside his flat, and everyone says goodnight, the opposite door slams too, and Dom is on the kerb beside him. "I'm staying with m' Billy tonight," he announces, then looks so proud. Billy blinks, pats his shoulder, and heads to unlock the door. Dom follows. "Have you any olives?" "In the fridge," says Billy, and doesn't inquire. He goes to change and get out the extra blankets. "Bed or sofa?" "Bed!" Billy sighs. Frickin' Dominic. "No, though," says Dom, reading his look, "I'll not put you on the couch. What'd be the point of staying at your house if you aren't there?" Oh. Oh, no. "What's wrong?" "Dommie... this may be out of bounds for me to be saying," (and Dom's eyebrows draw together, a look of, What bounds?), "but I was thinking, and I think there may be something you don't see." He is almost certain at this moment; this is truth, normal, inevitable. Dom nods slowly. "...The back of my head." He sits on the back of the sofa. Billy giggles, then bites his tongue. "I meant lines. Lines between people. Like a different line between strangers and acquaintances and friends and family, all those different people with particular ways we're supposed to be acting. The line between me and you," he draws in the air with a finger, something inside him sinking to define it so sharply. "You don't see it, do you?" Dom's expression is changing, subtly only, and almost too fast to read. But: comprehension, embarrassment, horror, disdain, to contemplation again. Then he smiles, same as ever. "I see a line between we two, Billy." He hops down from his perch, facing him steadily. "The one that goes from here," he places two fingers over is heart, "to here," and traces a line perpendicular to the blue one, touching Billy's chest. "And you're right. I can't always see to tell apart those things you were listing. But I can only be what I am, and act as I feel. And besides, follow lines that separate people? Why?" He steps back. Billy's mind is whirling. "They're blue. Is yours blue?" Dom looks at him, that frank gaze locking him in place. "Nn, red. It's red. Where's this blue line, again?" He squints at the space between them. Billy traces it with his index finder, waist-level and holding. "Okay," says Dom. He turns his back, clambering agile onto the tall part of the sofa, turning. Gathering himself, he leaps into the air, legs tucked high, a messy jump that doesn't care how it lands. And crashes into Billy, knocking them both to the floor. Dom's hand is curled protectively around the back of Billy's head as they impact, then they lay together breathless for awhile. Dom's cheek presses against his and moves, a touch bristly. "Well? Did I clear it?" That voice in his ear, low and excited. "...You did." He did. He did. Cleared it all away. "So now what?" A kind of dazed amazement is taking Billy over. Dom. Sitting up, pulling back to look him in the eyes. "Anything at all." :~

Billy claims the shower first, and within the five-minute interval (oh, ten at the most), Dominic is breathing sleep-slow. The suspicious bedspread has been shucked off onto the floor, and Dom's patchy sleeping bag is draped over the whuffling lump on the bed. There is plenty of room for two to lay without touching - these two, at least - but they don't bother with that, either. :~: There are caves, in this part of the country, which have bats and blind white crickets and weird glittery rock formations. And up on the peaks there are frozen waterfalls with icicle trickles and cascade stalactites. And views ~ everywhere another incredible view. Billy is reading, though. And Dom reins himself in from pointing out every panorama or interestingly-shaped boulder as their little car navigates the curves of the road south through the Great Smoky Mountains. Because sneaking glances of Billy's face, emoting rawly, absorbed in his book? Is every bit as great, to Dom's way of thinking. :~: Billy is in a mood. Dom tells him so. "Rush hour in Atlanta, Dominic. And will ye just-- oh, roll down the window!" "T's too hot. It'll never dry that way." He fans his hands, smirking. "Don' know what they've been telling you in L.A. and I don' care. Putting on nail varnish during a tailback will never be cool." There is quiet for a while. The elevated roads and multicoloured buildings give the city an alien look, all lemon and lavender, and almost clean under the smog. Dom shifts in a way that means what little restraint he has is running out. "No, Dom." "C'mon. Please? Just the left foot, then." "I am not. Painting. Your toenails. While you're driving." :~: They have fresh oranges from a touristy roadside stand, and candy bars and bottles of soda in a little cooler. The pace is steady-- "Fffuck!" No more than a dun flash careening from behind a stand of trees. Dom slams on the brakes, and everything spins hard and there is a noise behind the shouts. But when the semi behind them has howled past and the dust under the tires has drifted up the road a bit, the engine is still running, sort of. He puts it in park, laughing high in his throat and shaking like anything, and shuts it all down. Looks at Billy, who is clutching his chest-belt. "Nice evasive action, there, mate." Dom coughs. "Thanks." From the ditch of the speed lane - and pointed the wrong way, to boot - they watch cars zooming by. "Did you see what it was?" "An armadillo?" Dom knuckles a pressure point in Billy's upper arm. "Heh. Guess who gets to drive the whole rest of the way, Bill?" Billy turns in time to watch the deer reach the opposite side of the dual carriageway and leap away into the sparse forest. "It's all right." Another barking laugh. Dom's head falls back against the rest, eyes squeezed shut. "We could have both just died." Billy's hand on his friend's forehead erases the lines that were gathering there. "We're all right." :~: The purple sky hangs oddly close as they ease down the boulevard, windows open to admit the salty breeze that hisses through the palm fronds even over the noise of the motor. "Finally here. Finally." Dom grunts. He is chewing down the last Baby Ruth like a starving man, the map crumpled onto the car floor. "We should do this again sometime, shou'n't we? It was... fun." No reply. "It's not still about that deer, is it?" The car slows even more as Billy leans a little to touch Dom's wrist. "It was a close call, but--" "Oh, it's not that. America is too big. No one country should take that long to cross by car. It's just... wrong." "But imagine if we'd ha' set this film of ours in California. Scuba diving's good there, too." There is a moment of silence for the horror of that much distance to cover in a cramped rental car. Dom's fingers thread into Billy's and rest there. "We'd have flown," he says fervently. The car crawls the last few metres into the driveway, then Billy kills the engine and they sit listening to the headlight alarm. Only a few times since then, and I'm not sure what made me choose this, other than it seemed Dommish, and I'm positive I'm going to have a bad spill any minute now. I take a little time at the edge of the floor, getting used to the roll and list of the skates, while he warms up to easily looping the floor, looking like grace personified. Maybe that's why I chose it. A good reason, I tell myself, but I do believe I am too mesmerised to listen. He swoops and closes on my position, making a tiny circle at the end of the stroke, moving like calligraphy. "Been awhile?" I nod. He holds out his hand to me. "It'll come back," he says, and we go. "I'm sure it will," I murmur, gripping his hand for support when I slip backwards. His arm bears me up, and I can see his muscles changing under coloured light. God, I love him. It's terrible to love someone this much, slow and unmelting like glaciers, that one's heart wants to flow and freeze around another person and keep them forever as they are. I'd rather see him moving like this; I want to know that he isn't still. We can move and be together, I tell my stupid fascinated heart, as we do just that, hand in hand at first and then letting go but still brushing, coming from behind and telling him with gentle touches, I'm here. That's all I say with my hands, over and over. That or, I'm falling! I don't know whether to wish him to understand. :~

Beta by . ~: They walked - no, strolled along the river, comfortably arm in arm. Lampposts marked a warm orange path, the summer night humid and humming with quieted life. Raucous laughter marred any romantic atmosphere, but that was to be expected. Billy was nearly doubled over. "I've seen a lot of good looks in the time I've known you, but that had t' be one of the best." "She certainly didn't expect it. None of them did. I don't suppose you did, either," mused Dom, almost to himself. "But why not, after all? I'm sure I can show you a better time than any o' those drunkards." "So you claim. I'll be holding you to that, remember." "And isn't this a good start? Nice walk by the river and all." Billy was slurring a bit, probably from too much laughing rather than alcohol, of which he had imbibed relatively little, although nobody watching would have guessed he was sober. "Where to next?" "Well. The night is still young. Wanna go get in trouble?" "Depends on the trouble. Aren't you supposed to be taking me on a date?" "Aye, but it's you. Don't want you to be bored. Imagine, my best mate bored on a date with m'self? I'd never live it down." Dom playfully tried to trip him. "Don't make me imagine it. You take your friends out often?" "This is something of a special case, actually. It's you." "So you've mentioned." "I'd not just take out any old best friend who comes my way. Mm, nope." They abandoned that line of conversation, as Dom was losing track of which bits were joke and which were serious, if any. "Are you hungry at all?" "Yeah, it's been awhile since afternoon tea. Is it time for dinner now, or supper?" "Dinner is first, I think. Sounds lighter somehow. Well, I know a decent place for either one." "Lead on!" It was near, just over a low, flat bridge and up a bright shop-lined waterfront and down a flight of wet stairs sinking into the street. Steam billowed up around them as they descended, issuing from cracks in the cement. The restaurant was small, a riot of red and white and yellow light, played to by a noisy, enthusiastic band and packed with people of similar temperment. Dinner was sukiyaki, dipped in raw egg, which was criminally delicious and a first for Dom. Billy snatched the bill when it came, and wouldn't let him see. "My treat. Sit down and finish your rice." "You'll get yours," threatened Dom darkly. "I'm buying next time." "Your perogative," was the reply, and Dom polished off his egg-soaked rice, mollified. There was a strange sparkle about Billy just then, Dom thought. Then, 'I want to go to Japan as soon as possible. This food is like--' But he was distracted before completing his simile, because Billy grabbed his hand and pulled him up and out a different door than they had come in. They ran across the street - Dom closed his eyes for that part, a bit sedated from all the starch - and into another doorway. The interior was dark, but loud music was happening. Billy slapped some tickets down on the counter and they continued through into a wide arena with sweeping colored lights and people traversing the floor in a circular flow. A chin settled on Dom's shoulder, a mischievious voice cackled directly into his ear, and a pair of roller skates were pressed into his hands. Billy wasn't comepletely unskilled on wheels, but Dom had been roller blading about Manchester and acting school for years. He could even stop himself without running into the wall (which seemed to be Billy's main strategy). The unrepentantly 80s music actually had him almost dancing. Dom grinned across the blur of bodies, easily picking out Billy, who was holding opposite him at the moment. He shook his head - he hadn't realized he missed roller skating. At the end of the song, lights pulsed and the DJ shouted, "COUPLE SKATE! Singles, clear the floor!" Dom swerved to head off the edge onto the carpeting, but was sideswiped barely a meter from safety. He and his assailant crashed to the floor together, knocking the wind out of him, but gentle, familiar hands helped him sit up. "Couple skate doesn't mean leave," Billy scolded. They clambered to their feet, joined hands, and skated - no, say danced - as well as they could. Dom turned effortlessly to pull Billy with both hands, spun them both in a slow circle, sped up and banked and trailed their hands along the wall... How could he say enough that it was strange? It should have felt stranger, no doubt. It was strange. Dreamlike. And good. Entirely unlike any date Dom had ever had, but that was to be expected. He kept his eyes on Billy's face most of the time, watching that odd sparkle light and light. Song after song, until it stopped fading anymore and just lit all the time, mesmeric. They finally stopped, entirely out of breath. "This's a great song," Dom gasped. "Coldplay, yeah?" "Shiver." "Okay." Billy took Dom's hand and pressed it to his own cheek, letting Dom feel a tremor there. Dom looked at him. "That's the song title." "Oh, I know." Eh. "Of course." They lay on the low benches until they could walk, turned in their skates, and turned themselves out into the cooling night. "That date seemed pretty well-planned to me, Bills." "I try," said Billy, "but it isn't quite over yet." He tipped his head back as they went, face pointed up toward misty stars, three fingertips lightly resting on Dom's shoulder. Abruptly, he turned. "This way." A dark stone walk led into a city park, well-walled with trees. Something standing in the moonlight, but not people-- "There was an ice sculpture contest here today. They're leaving them to melt..." There was an enormous, round-scaled fish, whiskered like a dragon. A life-sized motorbike that looked a far sight nicer than the one Dom had back in Manchester. A waterspout rising from a choppy frozen ocean. An angel, wings spread and illuminated by starlight. What appeared to be a campfire, opaque and glistening, complete with a surrounding ring of stones. Dom exclaimed in delight to find a Weta beetle, larger than even in life, chiseled carefully from the ice. "Dare you to lick it," he said. "You." Dom did, crunching gleefully on its antennae. "Refreshing!" Billy sat on a bench in the center of the display. Soon Dom joined him, watching and listening to the sculptures drip and the muffled nighttime city sounds, New Zealand noises all around. "This is amazing. Those wings..." "I like the fire," said Billy quietly, sparking bright. Dom looked at his friend closely. "Something different about you tonight, Billy." "Anything different about you, Dom?" He blinked, surprised. "I don't know. What do you think?" Billy looked him in the eye for the first time in an hour, searchingly, quite near. "I think maybe so. How'd you like to find out?" The ice glittered, seeming to draw silence in about them. "Yeah." He breathed deep. "I should know something like that." "Guess what." "What?" Billy leaned against him, heads together side-by-side. "I'm scared out of my mind," Billy told him in a whisper. Then turned, slowly. Turned their faces toward each other, moved in a way he never had. Found Dom's mouth with his own; cautious, warm, shaking. Seeking. Found that Dom kissed back; cool from the ice, nervous, yielding, affectionate and brave. Strange. Natural. Sparked like stars. :~: {omake}

They ate together and she followed him about the dance floor, and he felt the coiling fall towards her like a sinkhole. Except, she didn't mean him any harm. She liked him. He watched his friend Ali and saw her liking him in the wild lights. Watched the others watching them. He blinked and sighed and kept dancing. Quite good live music was blasting too loud, and the motion of people on the floor was becoming too piecy, choppy as rough water. Billy wasn't drinking, but that didn't help enough. "I have a cold," he told her, drawing back. This wasn't what he'd intended. This would be reversed, giving up when he'd promised-- Her look was one of rebuke. "So share," she said, leaning in, pulling in. Billy slid forward, blinking backwards, eyes flickering open briefly. His head tipped, trying to hear, panic eating through the walls of the world, and then their mouths were touching. Unreal, surreal. She kissed him a question, and he bent the truth, not terribly far. I like you. ...But I love him. No kiss can say that unless the listening lips already understand. :~: Maybe it'll take you there. And maybe it won't. He wrote a letter and burned it. Wrote another, and burned it worse, tore it to little bits beforehand. It wasn't supposed to be an effigy, he told himself crossly, it was supposed to be sent. There is an easier way, his self replied, startling him so badly that he dropped burned scraps of paper all over the floor. He stared down at the black random snow over medium oak, nudged it into flaky ash with a toe, then went to get a broom. And a phone. Billy sweated. He sat on the floor, running a thumb over and over the plastic cover on the display of his mobile. Smearing the little bit of oil from skin left there, all to one grain and flow. He bent nearer and made a crosshatch pattern with a fingertip, transparent plaid atop Dom's number, digital and ready. Set it on end on the floor. Stood, backing away. Deep breaths, deep shivery breaths, and a cough, and. "I love you. No, I'm in--" He whirled and retreated to the window, shaking. The cool air and the heat (blooming up the glass) only reminded him again. :~: It was a year, all the way back to winter again before Dom asked Billy if he loved Ali. Billy went numb and shaky and horrified and fell apart a little and didn't really answer, no. Since then he knew Dom was worrying. Good. More letters, after all, and phone confessions which aborted into rambling jokes and the safer sort of mind-reading. The sort that doesn't pry, only accepts. Because Dom was good at that. But he asked again in the early spring, visiting on a day that smelled like forever, and Billy was silent and looked up at the sky. "What does that mean? Don't you?" "I lo--" and his words fell away, all unintentional. "What? Yes? Billy." Dom was looking at him, golden (but that was only the sunlight, wasn't it, hitting him just so?) and almost unfamiliar with that shine over his eyes. And. "No." Said Billy, "O' course I do, but, just. No. Not like ye'd think, after all this time." "Really." Billy pulled his hands into his sleeves, oddly chilled. "Then..." The why? stayed in Dom's mouth, where it belonged. It could just wait there. Like they'd all been waiting. And Ali never asked. :~: (Part two is here.)

Title: HAISAI Author: Starring: Would have been Dom/Billy, with lots of others to party with. Rating: PG Disclaimer: The way that I can imagine is not the true Way. Notes: Unfinished! This thing has been lurking on my hard drive for ages ~ time to give it some air. Posted to participate in weekend. Self-indulgent setting!fic, sending our lotrips people to the place I lived during my year abroad. Long-ago beta by . ~: Dom knew he was finally getting used to air commuting when he arrived at the airport in Okinawa not even tired. The time difference was slight - no worse than flying from Chicago to L.A., and the trip actually seemed shorter. Not like the transatlantic flights that used to destroy him between London and the States. Not even-- but Dom was distracted at this point in his thoughts by the rows of orchids decorating the disembarking passage. Leading out to the gates, into the main lobby, and how odd to allow smoking in an airport, and thank goodness he had his currency changed in Kansai International when he entered the country, because it was certainly too late for that now. There was a-- ah, good, they bothered to put english signs up. For all his cramming in the weeks before (and on the plane), the writing system eluded him completely. Gate twelve... gate twelve... And there it was. He plunked himself down in one of those ugly plastic seats - oddly low, here, and angled backwards - and fixed his eyes on the sky outside. Only a little light still lingered from the sunset, and he could see nothing concrete of the island, only water and lights. The flight from Tokyo was scheduled to arrive twenty-five minutes after his, and he'd be damned if he wasn't going to meet them. He wriggled in his seat. Vacation! Japan! Bills and Viggo and Orli! And Miranda and Sean and Lawrence and Andy joining them in a few days, and Elijah if he could squirm out of some dire previous commitment. He cracked open a box of the chocolate-covered biscuit sticks he'd got out of a vending machine in Osaka and crunched on them while he threaded one of the silver coins with the hole in the middle onto his necklace. It clinked brightly with Ali's engagement washer, and he grinned, and leaned back, and thought about his friends flying through the air towards him, and closed his eyes - just for a minute - against the annoying white lights. * He woke suddenly when something heavy landed on him, crushing the air out of his lungs. Somethings. Moving and loud and sharp knees, and he hugged his attacker happily, and learned it was Orlando without even opening his eyes. With Billy close behind, a carry-on flopping over his shoulder to smack into Dom but neither caring much as they greeted each other. Billy hauled him to his feet, and Viggo pounced and knocked their skulls together, and Dom bit his tongue hard upon impact but wasn't about to complain. And then there was a massive hug, a confusing, mutliperson hug, and they'd towed him down the terminal quite a ways before he started understanding what they were saying. "Viggo's been here before. You speak Japanese, too, don't you?" "Not much, but I could probably get by." "You could probably get by anywhere," put in Dom, thinking of Viggo's day-long disappearance in Berlin before the premiere of Return of the King. He had reappeared with what was essentially a locomoting party trailing after him. "You'd make a good Buddhist monk. Everyone would give you food." The corners of Viggo's mouth twitched up, and he eyed Dom's Pocky brazenly. "All right!" Dom surrendered the box to his friends, nabbing one last piece. He tucked it under his lip, letting it point down out of his mouth, then manoeuvred it around with his tongue, sucking the chocolate off the tip. This so occupied his mind that he nearly fell down the escalator, but Billy steadied him hastily. "Still asleep, are we?" Dom was all set to say, "I'm not even tired, though," around his Pocky. But was distracted again when Billy's teeth latched onto the other end of said biscuit stick and, after a moment spent twinkling at Dom, bit more than half of what remained clean off. "Hey, get your own!" is what Dom tried to say then, but they had reached the bottom of the escalator somehow, and he stumbled again. Billy still had ahold of his arm, though, so nothing inauspicious was allowed to happen. Orli took Dom's backpack then, handing it off to Viggo. "Bedtime for Sblommie. And it's not even nine o'clock!" "How about we get some food first?" Viggo had a faraway look, like Aragorn tracing over a map with his mind. "Not a word to BK about this, but I know a place near here that sells the curry of your life." "The Curry Of Your Life?" Orlando; sleepy, but intrigued. "Sounds enlightening. I could go for some curry. Would it be spicy?" "If you want." Viggo was describing the relative hotness system of japanese curry, but Dom couldn't listen anymore. He yawned, cracking his jaw. "Admit it. You're about to keel over," Billy muttered into Dom's ear. Dom giggled, sounding silly even to himself. "Maybe. Think the excitement's shorted out my brain." "Fair enough. Sleep in the taxi?" "Don't mind if I do." Dom put an arm over Billy's shoulders and leaned. "In the taxi, y' wanker! Not here!" They bumped through Alien Processing, handed over paperwork and passports and visas, and were let pass with barely a glance from security. (There were plenty of Americans in the crowd, Dom noticed vaguely - mostly military, from the look of them.) Then to the baggage claim, where he had to split off to find his luggage. It wasn't the fiasco he had expected. Nearly everyone else had theirs already, and Dom's bags were circling the conveyor belt and looking lonely. He rescued them and put them on one of those useful little rolly-carts waiting nearby, pushed off to collect the others. Who, it seemed, had been quicker than he to find everything, and were now waiting patiently by the oversized brown doors. Together they pushed into the receiving gate - a wide glassed-in chamber, surrounded by tropical aquaria - and made their way through the last checkpoint. "Maxine!" Viggo's voice made several people turn and look, and Dom couldn't blame them. But he already had ahold of the person whose attention he sought, and was embracing her warmly. "I thought you couldn't make it!" Maxine was perhaps sixty-five, taller than Dom but shorter than Viggo, with a tidy puff of grey hair and a kind, clever face. "Oh," she said, smiling and patting his back, "Bill's eyes aren't what they used to be, but he said he could spare me this one evening. And I brought the van, so... How was the flight? You'll have to introduce me," she waved, indicating his three companions. Her accent was unmistakably American. Viggo gave her their names, and she bowed to each of them, smiling in a friendly - edging on amused - manner. "Come, then, you must be exhausted. Did you want to stop for groceries before you go to the rental mansion?" "How about that curry place in Naha, is that still there?" Viggo wasn't going to let that idea slide, apparently. "Yes. Craving curry?" "I can't tell you how long it's been since I had a proper beef curry." "But you must have the recipe." He was grinning. "It isn't the same! You of all people would understand that." "And lucky for you, I do. Let's get your luggage, then." She took Orli's carry-on from him, touching his shoulder (probably in sympathy for the shadows under his eyes), and led the way outside. The humidity (the same wet heat from when Dom had disembarked, only, he'd forgotten by now) bathed them in a sudden blast as the outer doors admitted them to the night. It was raining cheerfully in fat drops, and all the lights of the parking lots and beyond flashed choppily off a ubiquitous reflective surface. Walking inside, Dom thought fuzzily, he was travelling from the outer world into some smaller bubble-universe, and the rules were probably different here, and he wished he'd read up a bit more beforehand. And that short walk out of the airport had felt a greater distance than any amount of time on a plane. He let his head nod down, but Billy reached around and caught his chin neatly. "How 'bout now? Tired now?" Dom declined to answer, only pushed his bags into the back of the champagne-coloured van. Then hauled his pillow around and bundled him into the bench seat in the back, and pushed him down, and flopped over into Billy's lap. Who grunted, but didn't protest, and just petted his hair a little and settled back sighing and fastened both their seatbelts as he could. * "Dom won, though," said Billy loudly, overhead. "He's been asleep since before the car started." "He sleeps when he reaches a new place," said Viggo, "and it's a good idea. Finding the tare of wherever you are, and resetting yourself to match." "Well, he's going to match my lap again this time, too." A Viggo laugh and an Orli laugh. "He does it on purpose. What will he do without you?" Dom protested their conversation with an annoyed groan and snaked his arms around Billy's waist. Without him, indeed. He had no intention of letting Billy out of reach until Dom was well-rested again. Or afterwards, either. But the car, the van was stopping, backing up and halting, and Viggo's unintelligible cry (either Vig-nonsense or Japanese) cut off when the door slammed. "We barely fit in that space," said Billy, sounding taken aback. "I mean, really. Dom, look." With effort, Dom lifted his head, pushing off against Billy's knee and shoulder to keep himself upright. The parking space - what the hell? - had walls, like a cage, which seemed only inches away from the sides of the car. "Uh, are we trapped in here, or what?" "Viggo escaped well enough. And is probably already on his second helping of curry." He made a drawn-out blink, as though his eyes hurt, and said, "Let's go." They pinballed in slow motion up and out the front door on the right - past the meter, which was controlling a set of tire spikes beneath the van. Followed the others into the restaurant on the corner, assimilating this dark alley and the high, neon-topped buildings all around, and the busy street barely a stumble away. Vending machines right there, different than even the ones they'd seen in Tokyo. Rain still plopping down, wet sidewalks, the odd covered gutters that Dom was afraid to step on, and frigid air conditioning as they passed through narrow automatic doors. Inside was bright, painful light, quite cramped, and with a few other people already seated in the hard-backed booths. They looked askance as the group of foreigners crammed themselves in around one table, with Viggo and Maxine on one side and everybody else on the other. Dom had never been happier to be in the middle ~ either way he slumped, there was a nice shoulder to lean on. There was a lot of fussing over poorly-translated menus and Dom was content to let Billy or somebody else order for him. Maxine did the honours and relayed requests for everyone when the waiter appeared, and he had such a grateful look when she spoke in Japanese. "He hasn't been studying, I think," she grinned at the rest of them when the young man had taken their orders back to the kitchen. "I know him, through a friend of a friend, and he ought to understand English well enough. But it seems he doesn't remember me." "How do you know Viggo, then, Maxine?" Billy asked curiously. "Ah, we rebels have to stick together, right?" she kept smiling, impishly proud. "Maxine and Bill are missionaries, and blacklisted by more than one government for 'subversive' peace-seeking activities." Dom sat up straight, interjecting a respectful "Wow!" "Our paths crossed while I was travelling here, and they've come to my rescue several times," Viggo continued. "The very best of people." Maxine shook her head fondly. "Speaking of the best of people, how is Henry?" "He's very well. He would have come with us, but he decided to keep with his part-time job instead." Viggo closed his eyes. "I'm so proud of him, in everything he does." He produced recent pictures from his wallet then, which, along with his ruffian-like driver's licence photo, kept everyone's interest until the waiter returned balancing an enormous tray of oblong plates. There was hardly room on the table for all those plates, particularly Viggo's, which seemed positively mountainous. At Dom's stare, he explained: "It's the Challenge Curry. If I eat the entire thing, it's free." Then he and Maxine chirped something in Japanese, and he tucked in enthusiastically. On Dom's plate there was a circular mass of white rice - the short-grain, sticky kind - and a small lake of curry sauce, swimming with sliced beef and melted cheese. Part of a soft-boiled egg appeared to be sunning itself on the rice beach. It smelled too good to hold off for long, but it seemed he was missing part of the process. He glanced at Maxine uncertainly. She smiled, or perhaps continued to smile. "Itadakimasu," she enunciated. "It means, 'I humbly partake.'" "Takakimas?" Dom fumbled. "Ii-ta-da-ki-maas'." She said again, letting him parrot her until he had it right. "Itadakimas'!" Billy and Orlando, although they had already started into their curries, mumbled it along with him. No one spoke for a while after that, only gasping occasionally when a mouth was burned. Until Orlando surrendered, groaning, "I can't believe how filling this stuff is," and pushing away his plate. Viggo made a cat smile and appropriated what was left of Orli's vegetarian curry, mixing it in with his own. Dom, still going strong, cheerfully scooped a bite out of Billy's curry. "This is the chicken?" "Yeh, you uncivillised-- HAH!" Billy's spoon clinked when he helped himself to Dom's plate. "Now, that's not bad. I'd get that next time." "Hey, I was saving the egg!" "Mix it in! It's good that way." "...Ah, all right. Hmm, a bit more of this, then." Dom had another spoonful off Billy's, then took some from Viggo's plate for each of them, since Billy couldn't reach. "Wanna try the beef and cheese, Orli?" Yawning, Orlando shook his head. "Hobbits!" Maxine mopped up her last bit of sauce with her last few grains of rice and sat back, laying her spoon neatly across the top right side of her dish. "Goch'sousama," said she, and Dom yawned hugely in the middle of mouthing the string of syllables back. :~: Annnd, that's all I've got. Goodnight. <3

Title: Absentee Ballots Authors: & Rating: PG Starring: Dom, Viggo, Billy Disclaimer: The way that I can imagine is not the true Way. Notes: Written to soothe us after the 2004 election. Originally posted here. I wrote the stuff before the pagebreak, and Puddle continued it. Thanks to for the most apt title. ~: It is three o'clock when his mobile vibrates in his pocket and makes him spill his drink. "Shite. Evey, love, hand me that towel, could you?" He opens his phone, mopping himself off. "'Ello?" "Still watching?" comes a familiar voice. "Viggo. 'Course I am, mate." There is a little stillness down the line that delineates their mutual distaste, backed by a slightly delayed echo of the same station playing in two far-apart houses. Dom glances at the redredred map and scoffs. "That cunting idiot for another four years, yeah? Sean's gonna be pissed." "And he's not the only one." Dom's mind eye shows him Viggo, in one of his political shirts, probably, sitting folded over on himself and with a crease between his eyebrows. And Sean, at his local campaign headquarters, exhausted and-- no. He revises it to Sean asleep at home, not worrying even in dreams, and wishes it true. "They're passing these bans, you know?" Viggo sighs. "I voted early today. California went to Kerry, obviously. Seems they need more of us in Ohio." "Wish I could've done something." Dom makes eye contact and nods his thanks as Jorge passes him yet another can and smiles grimly. It feels lovely against his forehead, drawing out a tiny portion of the heat of Hawaiian November that has been collecting inside his skull. "All this political stuff. Makes me nauseous. We had t' put the criers to bed an hour ago. ...Wish I could've actually done something." "You do what you can. We all do." This is not Dom's country, for all that he lives here. "Get me out o' here, man." "There's a six o'clock to LAX, if you're interested--" "It's still America--" "And I can join you on the transfers towards Glasgow." Viggo waits a moment. "Does that strike your fancy?" Cool weather, sane government, and Billy. The thought's enough to make this headache unclench a little from around his brain. "Yes," he says slowly, and with great satisfaction; he has a week, at least. "Yes it does. ...What're you wearing?" Viggo just laughs and books their flights. :~: "Let's play a game," Billy suggests with that thing he gets in his voice when he knows something. They've only just got into his flat and opened their beers, but Dom's been awake for hours and hours (so has Vig), and he doesn't know the exact number of them-- obviously more hours than it takes to count the millions of people in Ohio. By hand, are they doing it, now? The extra factor is Billy, though. He's being his old enigmatic self. He knows something that Dom doesn't know. So Dom glances at Viggo, but garners no clues, for he's only inspecting a set of his own black and whites on the wall. Dom wonders if, in transit between Billy's car and the flat, Billy caught some bit of news through a secret source. He squints. "I can tell you have a secret, you know, Bill." Billy widens his eyes comically. He looks insane, as per usual. "Nothin' you both don't know already. We're goin'e go around and guess what each others' most hated... ehm... ye know. Most despised trait of Bush's is. 'S'at sound reasonably--" "Yours is the environmental policy," Viggo cuts in, tossing his gaze over his shoulder at Billy. "An' I know what yours is, too, Flower. Where's Ali?" "Flower?" Dom grins and mutters bemusedly, "That's a new one, Mudpile." He sets his elbows on his knees, looks down at himself and thinks: this is how Viggo was sitting when he rang from Cali. "Mudpile?" Billy asks of them, grinning. "Ehm, Ali's walkin' Horatio, she left a note on the fridge." Viggo stalks over to the couch Dom's sat on and trickles down. He smirks at each of them in turn. "... Horatio?" "Least Horatio's his real name," Billy says. "Yours," Dom says, picking his head up to look at Viggo, "is the war." "Well." Viggo puts his back against the sofa. Dom looks up at Billy, who is sitting in the chair next to the couch frowning. Frowning straight at Dom, no less. "How does Viggo know yours and I... I don't... think I do. 'Nless it's somethin' we've already said." Dom and Viggo share a look, but when Dom's eyes rake back over to Billy's, he regrets. "It's..." Dom sighs. "You know me, Bill, come on." Billy stares. "We have not discussed it thus far," Viggo supplies. "You know this, Billy. You said you knew it before we even said anything." "Yeah, but... I..." He shakes his head in a contained way. "Keepsecondguessingmyself," he says under his breath, then: "His stance on gay marriage?" Viggo chuckles deeply. Dom elbows him and nods, smiling softly, at Billy. Some little lines spring up around Billy's eyes and brows that aren't normally there. They say: Are you guys...? "Look what you did, Mudpile," Dom whines. "Made Billy think we're shagging!" Viggo laughs harder, and Billy joins in a little. Dom motions for him to join them on the sofa-- pats the space between himself and Viggo-- and Billy sets his beer down so he can dart right over. Dom wraps around Billy immediately, both arms, his head and even one of his legs, and Viggo comes in a few seconds after. Billy lets his head stack on top of Dom's and puts his arms around them both. "Guess I'm kinda glad," Billy quietly utters, the mood instantly morphed by the tone of his voice, "things turned out the way they did." "Why?" Dom squeaks, because he is suddenly shot through the heart with dread-- is this Billy? Billy laughs. "Because I get te see you guys, ye great English idiot!" Viggo snorts; Dom presses his head further into the side of Billy's neck. A moment of silence comes and goes. "Ye wouldn't be here if Kerry won," Billy says like it's the saddest thing imaginable and like Dom and Viggo are not in any way allowed to continue that train of thought. But if Billy wanted that, he should've changed the subject straightaway. Just as Dom opens his mouth to spill out something he's not even cognitively recognised as English yet, Viggo says, "No, we'd've flown you down to LA to make you party with us, Billy." "Really?" Dom wants to answer that, at least, but Viggo beats him to it again. "You don't really doubt me, do you." "No. What were you gonna say, Dom?" Billy curls his warm hand around Dom's waist. "I'm kinna glad, too," Dom provides expediently. "How I've missed Britain. Scotland in all its cold, pissing rain throughout November glory." "The sky only weeps for you, Dom." There is a smile in Billy's voice. "You've got'e spend more time here, else it'll just be sunny all winter long." When Viggo disengages and rolls to his feet, Dom feels part of his security disconnect and walk away with him. He's only going to the loo, but. Billy wraps his unused half around Dom; Dom very carefully tugs his chest away from the full-frontal contact Billy wants. His heart is making too much of a racket in there; Billy's heart might call the landlord and complain. Once it's more or less taken care of, Dom's muscles are quivering but he finds the words: "That's the point, silly Billy. I've been craving this place. And you know what happens when I crave someplace." "Yeah, you usually tend te crave quietly. When's the last time ye went te New Zealand? And you've not been here in over a year, ye know." "But it's--" "I named my dog after you." Dom shifts his head slightly. There isn't much else he can do. "... I... thought you named him Horatio." "Horatio the best mate." "Did you tell Ali why you named him?" Dom asks before he can process. "No." Oh. Only now does Dom smile, because Billy's just restored some of Dom's lost (kidnapped, tied bound and gagged, stabbed, died a horrible death, thankyouverymuch Mister Bush) optimism and, as it turns out, there actually are things more important than American politics. Dom relaxes and dips and melts and lets his chest touch Billy's. :~
